instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2442: What is A2442? A2442 is a model number for a 14 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2021 M1 with EMC 3650, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02098..
definitions.820-02098: What is 820-02098? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No keyboard or Trackpad
threads.message:
Originally came in with liquid damage and a damaged trackpad connector and cable. I replaced the cable and trackpad connector and repaired a trace for the keyboard on pin 6 and that worked fine. It was sent back working, customer (who is another shop) was responsible for putting it completely back together, sent it back a week later saying it didn't work. There were more traces broken this time on the connector. Traces for pins 1,3,5,7,9 were broken so I repaired those but still no trackpad or keyboard. Unable to verify whether either work in recovery mode due to the customer breaking the power button so I'm waiting for a replacement to test that. Here are the voltages I took. 

1 - 1.8v
2 - 1.8v
3 - 1.8v
4 - 1.8v
5 - 0v
7 - 1.8v
9 - 0v
11 - 0v
12 - 3.3v
13 - 0v
14 - 1.8v
15 - 5v
17 - GND
19 - 1.8v
21 - 1.8v
23 - GND

IPD_SPI_EN - 0V

These voltages are with the trackpad connected.
Tried with another trackpad and cable. Also verified the traces from the connector to the components are good. 

Any help would be appreciated. Thanks.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2442</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No keyboard or Trackpad
threads.message:
You can use SV101/11 pads to simulate power button.
Solder a switch with 5-10cm wires on any of these pads pair.

However, trackpad always work on SPI mode; even before loading macOS.

Check the circuits from page 124; pay atention to UT355.
